title: Chronic Inflammation
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Chronic Inflammation Overview Chronic inflammation is a persistent, low-grade inflammation that can silently damage tissues and organs over time. Unlike acute inflammation, which is a short-term response to injury or infection, chronic inflammation can contribute to a wide range of diseases, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, cancer, and autoimmune disorders. Properties condition_type: Inflammatory Condition symptoms: - Fatigue - Fever - Rash - Joint pain - Muscle stiffness - Weight gain/loss risk_factors: - Obesity - Poor diet - Stress - Smoking - Alcohol consumption - Infections treatment_approaches: - Anti-inflammatory diet - Stress reduction - Exercise - Medication (NSAIDs, corticosteroids) - Supplementation Relationships ASSOCIATED_WITH_BIOMARKER::hsCRP WORSENED_BY_CONDITION::Diabetes REDUCED_BY_DRUG::Turmeric REDUCED_BY_DRUG::Ashwagandha REDUCED_BY_DRUG::Coenzyme Q10 REDUCED_BY_INTERVENTION::Red Light Therapy

title: Diabetes
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Diabetes Overview Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Glucose is vital to your health because it's an important source of energy for the cells that make up your muscles and tissues. It's also your brain's main source of fuel. The underlying cause of diabetes varies by type. But no matter what type of diabetes you have, it can lead to excess sugar in your blood. Too much sugar in your blood can lead to serious health problems. Properties condition_type: Metabolic Disease symptoms: - Frequent urination - Increased thirst - Increased hunger - Weight loss - Fatigue - Blurred vision risk_factors: - Obesity - Physical inactivity - Family history - Ethnicity - Age treatment_approaches: - Medication - Insulin therapy - Dietary changes - Exercise Relationships ASSOCIATED_WITH_BIOMARKER::Glucose WORSENED_BY_INTERVENTION::Keto Diet IMPROVED_BY_INTERVENTION::Exercise COMPLICATES::Chronic Inflammation

title: Ashwagandha
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Ashwagandha Overview Ashwagandha is a revered herb in traditional Indian medicine, classified as an adaptogen due to its remarkable capacity to help the body adapt to various stressors, both physical and psychological. It is increasingly popular in modern wellness for its multifaceted health benefits. Properties drugbank_id: DB11440 synonyms: - Withania somnifera - Indian Ginseng description_short: An adaptogenic herb known for stress reduction, cognitive support, and energy enhancement. mechanism_of_action_summary: Modulates the HPA axis, reduces cortisol levels, and has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. drug_class: Herbal Supplement Relationships REDUCES_BIOMARKER::Cortisol IMPROVES_CONDITION::Stress RELATED_TO::Chronic Inflammation HAS_EFFECT_ON::Sleep Quality

title: Coenzyme Q10
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Coenzyme Q10 Overview Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) is a naturally occurring antioxidant that is essential for cellular energy production, particularly within the mitochondria. It is also known for its cardiovascular benefits and its ability to protect cells from oxidative damage. Properties drugbank_id: DB00170 synonyms: - Ubiquinone - Ubiquinol description_short: A vitamin-like substance vital for cellular energy production and antioxidant protection. mechanism_of_action_summary: Facilitates ATP synthesis in the mitochondrial electron transport chain and acts as a scavenger of free radicals. drug_class: Nutritional Supplement Relationships IMPROVES_CELLULAR_COMPONENT::Mitochondria REDUCES_CONDITION::Chronic Inflammation USED_FOR::Cardiovascular Health IS_BIOMARKER::CoQ10 Level

title: Creatine
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Creatine Overview Creatine is a naturally occurring compound that plays a vital role in the body's energy production system, particularly in muscle and brain cells. It is widely used as a dietary supplement by athletes and bodybuilders to improve strength, enhance exercise performance, and support muscle growth. Properties drugbank_id: DB00148 synonyms: - N-Methyl-N-guanyl-glycine description_short: A compound involved in energy production, popular as a supplement for athletic performance. mechanism_of_action_summary: Replenishes ATP, aids in muscle energy, and supports high-intensity exercise. drug_class: Nutritional Supplement Relationships HAS_MECHANISM_OF_ACTION::Mitochondria IMPROVES_CONDITION::Chronic Inflammation RELATED_TO::Exercise USED_FOR::Athletic Performance Health Coach Insights (from recent video) During a recent health coach video, several key insights about creatine supplementation were shared: Beyond Muscle Growth: While widely known for muscle and strength, the coach emphasized creatine's significant benefits for brain health, including improved cognitive function, memory, and protection against neurological diseases. This is particularly relevant for individuals looking to support mental acuity as they age. Dosage & Loading Phase: For general health and cognitive benefits, a daily dose of 3-5g was recommended, without necessarily needing a loading phase for sustained use. For acute performance gains, a loading phase (20g/day for 5-7 days) followed by maintenance was suggested. Safety Profile: Reaffirmed creatine's excellent safety profile, even with long-term use, dispelling common myths about kidney damage in healthy individuals. Hydration was highlighted as key. Synergistic Effects: Mentioned that creatine works synergistically with other supplements like Coenzyme Q10 for enhanced mitochondrial function and energy production. Publications & Further Reading Here are some of the interesting publications mentioned by the health coach that warrant further investigation: Cognitive Benefits: "Creatine supplementation and brain health: A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials." (Journal of Nutritional Biochemistry, 2023) Long-Term Safety: "Effects of creatine supplementation on renal function in athletes: A systematic review and meta-analysis." (Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 2022) Mitochondrial Function: "Creatine and coenzyme Q10 in neurodegenerative diseases: A review." (Mitochondrion, 2021) General Review: "International Society of Sports Nutrition position stand: safety and efficacy of creatine supplementation in exercise, sport, and medicine." (Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 2017) Feel free to expand this note with your personal research, additional insights, or links to related concepts to further enrich your knowledge graph.

title: MCT8 Oil
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: MCT8 Oil (Caprylic Acid) Overview MCT oil, particularly formulations rich in caprylic acid (C8), has gained popularity for its ability to quickly provide energy and support brain function. Unlike long-chain fatty acids, MCTs are rapidly absorbed and converted into ketones, which can serve as an efficient fuel source, especially beneficial in ketogenic diets. Properties drugbank_id: DB16584 synonyms: - Caprylic Acid MCT - C8 MCT Oil description_short: A specific type of medium-chain triglyceride oil (C8) valued for quick ketone production and brain energy. mechanism_of_action_summary: Bypasses typical fat digestion, rapidly absorbed and metabolized into ketones by the liver, providing an alternative fuel source for the brain and body. drug_class: Nutritional Supplement Relationships REQUIRES_INTERVENTION::Keto Diet INCREASES_BIOMARKER::Ketones AFFECTS_ORGAN::Brain SOURCE_OF::Energy

title: Turmeric
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Turmeric Overview Turmeric, particularly its main active compound curcumin, has been extensively studied for its medicinal properties. It is a powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant, which may help in managing various health conditions. Properties drugbank_id: DB11283 synonyms: - Curcuma longa - Curcumin description_short: A spice widely used in traditional medicine for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects. mechanism_of_action_summary: Modulates numerous molecular targets involved in inflammation and oxidative stress pathways. drug_class: Herbal Supplement Relationships REDUCES_CONDITION::Chronic Inflammation CONTAINS::Curcumin USED_FOR::Joint Pain

title: Keto Diet
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Keto Diet Overview The ketogenic diet is a popular eating pattern known for its potential to promote weight loss, improve blood sugar control, and enhance cognitive function. By significantly restricting carbohydrates, the body enters a state of ketosis, where it burns fat for fuel, producing ketones. Properties intervention_type: Dietary Intervention mechanism_of_action: Induces ketosis, shifting the body's primary fuel source from carbohydrates to fats. dosing_protocol: Typically involves consuming <50g net carbs per day, moderate protein, and high fat. contraindications: - Type 1 diabetes - Pancreatic disease - Liver conditions - Fat-malabsorption disorders side_effects: - Keto flu (fatigue, headache, nausea) - Constipation - Nutrient deficiencies interactions: May interact with medications for diabetes or blood pressure. duration: Can be short-term or long-term, depending on health goals and individual tolerance. frequency: Daily adherence to dietary macronutrient ratios. timing: Consistent adherence throughout the day. Relationships MAY_IMPROVE_CONDITION::Diabetes REQUIRES_SUPPLEMENT::MCT8 Oil AFFECTS_CELLULAR_COMPONENT::Mitochondria ASSOCIATED_WITH_BIOMARKER::Ketones

title: Red Light Therapy
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Red Light Therapy Overview Red light therapy, also known as photobiomodulation (PBM), uses red and near-infrared light to deliver therapeutic benefits. It works by stimulating cellular function, particularly within the mitochondria, to improve energy production, reduce inflammation, and accelerate healing. Properties intervention_type: Light Therapy mechanism_of_action: Penetrates skin to stimulate mitochondria, promoting ATP production, reducing inflammation, and enhancing cellular repair. dosing_protocol: Varies; typically 10-20 minutes per session, 3-5 times per week. contraindications: - Photosensitivity - Active skin conditions (e.g., severe eczema) - Pregnancy (consult physician) side_effects: - Mild redness or irritation (rare) - Eye strain (if unprotected) interactions: None significant known; may enhance effects of some topical treatments. duration: Acute or chronic depending on condition; often used long-term for chronic issues. frequency: Daily or multiple times per week for optimal results. timing: Can be used anytime; morning or evening sessions may affect circadian rhythm. Relationships IMPROVES_CELLULAR_COMPONENT::Mitochondria REDUCES_CONDITION::Chronic Inflammation USED_FOR::Pain Management IMPROVES_BIOMARKER::ATP

title: Health Goals: John Doe
date: Sat Nov 01 2025 08:45:32 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Health Goals: John Doe Active Goals Goal 1: Reduce LDL Cholesterol Target: Reduce LDL cholesterol to under 100 mg/dL Current Value: 142 mg/dL (as of May 1, 2025) Timeline: 6 months (by November 2025) Priority: High Action Plan Increase soluble fiber intake to 10g+ daily Add 30 minutes of cardio exercise 3x weekly Incorporate plant sterols/stanols into diet Reduce saturated fat consumption to <7% of daily calories Take omega-3 supplement (2-3g daily) Measurements & Tracking Full lipid panel test quarterly Weekly food journal focusing on fiber and fat intake Monthly check-in with health coach Scientific Rationale Research indicates that increasing soluble fiber can reduce LDL cholesterol by 5-10%. Combined with regular cardiovascular exercise and omega-3 supplementation, this plan addresses both dietary and lifestyle factors contributing to elevated cholesterol. Goal 2: Improve Sleep Quality Target: Increase sleep quality score to 85+/100 Current Value: 65/100 Timeline: 3 months (by August 2025) Priority: Medium Action Plan Establish consistent sleep-wake schedule (10:30 PM - 6:30 AM) Create technology-free wind-down routine (30 min before bed) Optimize bedroom environment (temperature, light, noise) Morning sunlight exposure within 30 minutes of waking Limit caffeine after 12 PM Measurements & Tracking Daily sleep tracking via Oura ring Weekly assessment of sleep quality metrics Sleep journal noting pre-sleep activities and quality Scientific Rationale Circadian rhythm optimization through consistent sleep-wake cycles and morning light exposure has been shown to improve sleep quality by 20-30%. Limiting evening blue light exposure helps with melatonin production and sleep onset. Goal 3: Optimize Vitamin D Levels Target: Achieve vitamin D level of 50-60 ng/mL Current Value: 28 ng/mL (insufficient) Timeline: 3 months (by August 2025) Priority: Medium Action Plan Supplementation with 4000 IU vitamin D3 daily 15-20 minutes of midday sun exposure (arms and legs) 3x weekly when possible Increase vitamin D-rich foods (fatty fish, egg yolks, fortified foods) Take supplement with fat-containing meal to improve absorption Measurements & Tracking Retest vitamin D levels after 3 months Track supplement adherence daily Log sun exposure in weekly health journal Scientific Rationale Research shows that each 1000 IU of vitamin D supplementation raises blood levels by approximately 5-10 ng/mL. Combined with moderate sun exposure and dietary sources, the target level should be achievable within the timeline. Goal 4: Reduce Inflammatory Markers Target: Reduce hsCRP to <1.0 mg/L Current Value: 1.8 mg/L Timeline: 6 months (by November 2025) Priority: Medium Action Plan Incorporate anti-inflammatory foods daily (berries, fatty fish, olive oil, leafy greens) Practice stress-reduction technique for 15 minutes daily Optimize sleep quality (see Goal 2) Maintain consistent exercise routine with focus on zone 2 cardio Consider Turmeric supplementation (1000mg with piperine daily) Explore Red Light Therapy for systemic inflammation Measurements & Tracking Retest hsCRP and homocysteine after 3 months Track anti-inflammatory food consumption Monitor stress levels using HRV measurements Scientific Rationale Dietary patterns rich in anti-inflammatory foods have been shown to reduce CRP by 20-40% over 3-6 months. Stress reduction techniques improve HRV and are associated with lower inflammatory markers when practiced consistently. Turmeric and Red Light Therapy offer additional support for inflammation reduction through distinct mechanisms. Goal 5: Enhance Mitochondrial Health Target: Improve cellular energy production and mitochondrial function Current Status: General fatigue, suboptimal cellular energy Timeline: 4 months (by September 2025) Priority: Medium Action Plan Consider Coenzyme Q10 supplementation (200mg daily) Incorporate more Keto Diet principles (e.g., occasional intermittent fasting, reduced refined carbs) Explore benefits of Red Light Therapy sessions Regular moderate-intensity Exercise to promote mitochondrial biogenesis Measurements & Tracking Track energy levels and fatigue daily Monitor exercise performance improvements Consider advanced cellular health markers if available Scientific Rationale Mitochondrial dysfunction is linked to fatigue and various chronic diseases. Coenzyme Q10 is vital for the electron transport chain in Mitochondria. Dietary strategies like the Keto Diet and interventions such as Red Light Therapy can optimize mitochondrial function and energy production.

knee discomfort As-Needed Supplements Supplement Dosage Conditions for Use Purpose Notes Melatonin 1.5mg Travel, significant sleep disruption Sleep initiation Use rarely, only when sleep cycle support, detoxification MCT8 Oil 1 tbsp Prior to workouts, during low-carb days Ketone production, energy Experimenting with ketogenic diet principles Supplement Details & Research Key Supplements Research Vitamin D3 Mechanism: Fat-soluble vitamin essential for calcium absorption and immune function Evidence Level: Strong Current Research: Studies show optimal range for overall health is 40-60 ng/mL Personalization Factors: Baseline level of 28 ng/mL indicates need for higher dosing Fish Oil Mechanism: Provides EPA/DHA omega-3 fatty acids that support cardiovascular health and reduce inflammation Evidence Level: Strong Current Research: Minimum effective dose for lipid effects appears to be 2-3g of combined EPA/DHA daily Personalization Factors: Current lipid panel shows benefit from increased dosage Magnesium Glycinate Mechanism: Supports over 300 enzymatic reactions, particularly important for muscle relaxation and sleep Evidence Level: Moderate Current Research: Glycinate form shows better absorption and fewer GI effects than oxide forms Personalization Factors: Sleep tracking shows improved deep sleep with consistent use Creatine Mechanism: Increases phosphocreatine stores in muscles, rapidly regenerating ATP for high-intensity activities. Evidence Level: Strong Current Research: Widely recognized for improving strength, power, and muscle mass in athletic populations. Personalization Factors: John's regular weight training and desire for performance enhancement. Coenzyme Q10 Mechanism: Essential component of the electron transport chain in Mitochondria, involved in ATP production and acts as a powerful antioxidant. Evidence Level: Moderate to Strong Current Research: Research supports its role in cardiovascular health, energy metabolism, and mitigating oxidative stress. Personalization Factors: John's slightly low CoQ10 levels and interest in mitochondrial health. Interactions & Contraindications Supplement Interactions Fish Oil + Magnesium: Complementary for cardiovascular health B-Complex + Magnesium: Synergistic for energy production and stress response Zinc + Copper: Monitoring copper intake due to zinc supplementation (obtaining from multivitamin) Medication Interactions Ibuprofen + Fish Oil: Both affect clotting; extra caution when using together No current prescription medications with known supplement interactions Timing Considerations Taking Vitamin D and B vitamins in morning due to potential sleep disruption Magnesium taken in evening to support relaxation and sleep quality Supplements requiring fat absorption (D3, fish oil) taken with meals containing healthy fats Supplement Quality Standards Brand Preferences Looking for GMP-certified manufacturing Third-party testing (USP, NSF, or ConsumerLab verification when available) Minimal excipients and allergens Current Trusted Brands Thorne Research (B-Complex, Magnesium) Nordic Naturals (Fish Oil) Pure Encapsulations (Vitamin D, Zinc) Jarrow Formulas (Probiotics) Effectiveness Tracking Observed Benefits Improved sleep initiation with evening magnesium (sleep onset reduced from 35 to 25 minutes) Reduced joint discomfort with Turmeric supplementation Better stress resilience with Ashwagandha cycles Increased strength and endurance during workouts with Creatine Areas for Optimization Current fish oil dosage likely insufficient based on latest cholesterol panel May benefit from methylated forms of B vitamins due to MTHFR gene variant Consider higher potency vitamin D during winter months Monitor MCT8 Oil intake as part of exploring ketogenic principles

title: Mitochondria
date: Sun Nov 02 2025 07:30:31 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content: Mitochondria Overview Mitochondria are crucial organelles within eukaryotic cells, often referred to as the 'powerhouses' of the cell. They are primarily responsible for generating the majority of the cell's supply of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), which is used as a source of chemical energy. This process, known as cellular respiration, is vital for nearly all metabolic activities. Properties go_id: GO:0005739 description_short: The 'powerhouses' of the cell, responsible for generating ATP through cellular respiration. Relationships PRODUCES::ATP AFFECTED_BY_INTERVENTION::Red Light Therapy AFFECTED_BY_DIET::Keto Diet ESSENTIAL_FOR_FUNCTION::Cellular Energy

title: Creatine Kinase
date: Sat Jan 31 2026 16:54:03 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)
content:
Creatine Kinase
Overview
Creatine Kinase (CK) is an enzyme found primarily in skeletal muscle, heart muscle, and the brain. It catalyzes the reversible conversion of creatine and ATP to phosphocreatine and ADP. This reaction serves as an energy buffer, allowing for the rapid regeneration of ATP during high-intensity activity.
When muscle or nerve cells are injured, CK leaks into the bloodstream, making it a key marker for tissue damage.
Isoforms
CK exists as three main isoenzymes (dimers of M and B subunits):

CK-MM (Skeletal Muscle): Accounts for 98% of CK in skeletal muscle and the vast majority of circulating CK in healthy individuals.
CK-MB (Heart Muscle): Found mainly in the heart (myocardium). Historically used to diagnose heart attacks (now largely replaced by Troponin).
CK-BB (Brain): Found in the brain and lungs. Rarely measured in blood as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier easily.

Clinical Significance

Rhabdomyolysis: Massive breakdown of muscle tissue leads to extremely high CK levels (>5,000 U/L, often >10,000). The released myoglobin can cause acute kidney injury.
Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack): CK-MB rises 4-6 hours after injury. Useful for detecting reinfarction shortly after an initial event (as it clears faster than Troponin).
Muscle Diseases: Elevated in muscular dystrophies (e.g., Duchenne) and inflammatory myopathies.
Statin-Induced Myopathy: Statins can cause muscle pain and mild to moderate CK elevations.
